CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers and their applications for optoelectronic device such as organic light - emitting diodes ( OLEDs ) , organic photovoltaic cells ( OPVs ) , and organic field - effect transistors ( OFETs ) since Heeger , MacDiarmid , and Shirakawa discovered conducting polymers in 1976.^1 As a result of the low - cost , light - weight , and flexibility advantages , optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers are a promising cost - effective alternative to inorganic materials - based microelectronics. Conjugated polymers can be classified as hole ( p - type ) or electron ( n - type ) transporting materials according to the type of orderly transferring charge carriers. Most of conjugated polymers are p - type semiconductors that have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade while much less attention has been devoted to n - type semiconducting polymers that have lagged behind their p - type counterparts. 2 Organic n - type materials are essential for the fabrication of organic p-n junctions , OPVs , n-channel OFETs , OLEDs , and complementary logic circuits. 3 The n - type building blocks are the core components in n - type semiconducting polymers. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are one of the classical n - type building blocks and can exhibit relatively high electron affinities , high electron mobilities , and excellent chemical , thermal , and photochemical stabilities. 4 These materials are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated. The widely used rylene diimides include perylene diimides ( PDIs , 1 ) and naphthalene diimides ( NDIs , 2 ) ( Figure 1 ). Zhan and co-workers reported the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer. 5 Top-gate OFETs based on this PDI- dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility ( μ e ) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , current on / off ratio ( I on / I off ) of 10^4 , and a low threshold voltage ( V th ) of 7 V in air. 6 Moreover , all - polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 1.5% ( AM1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 ). 7-9 Facchetti et al. reported a conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene ; 10 OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate , bottom - contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μ e of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with I on / I off > 10^5 . 11 The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide ( 3 ) and thiophene imide ( 4 ) ( Figure 1 ). A few literatures reported phthalimide - containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s , 12 a polyaniline derivative , 13 and a polythiophene derivative.

Let's think step by step.

1. Conjugated polymers
2. p-type semiconductors
3. n-type semiconducting polymers
4. Organic n-type materials
5. Rylene diimides (perylene diimides, NDIs)
6. PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer
7. Conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene
8. Phthalimide
9. Thiophene imide
10. Poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s
11. A polyaniline derivative
12. A polythiophene derivative

| Material Name |
| --- |
| conjugated polymers |
| p-type semiconductors |
| n-type semiconducting polymers |
| organic n-type materials |
| rylene diimides (perylene diimides, NDIs) |
| PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer |
| conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene |
| phthalimide |
| thiophene imide |

| a polyaniline derivative |
| a polythiophene derivative |

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers and their applications for optoelectronic device such as organic light - emitting diodes ( OLEDs ) , organic photovoltaic cells ( OPVs ) , and organic field - effect transistors ( OFETs ) since Heeger , MacDiarmid , and Shirakawa discovered conducting polymers in 1976.^1 As a result of the low - cost , light - weight , and flexibility advantages , optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers are a promising cost - effective alternative to inorganic materials - based microelectronics. Conjugated polymers can be classified as hole ( p - type ) or electron ( n - type ) transporting materials according to the type of orderly transferring charge carriers. Most of conjugated polymers are p - type semiconductors that have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade while much less attention has been devoted to n - type semiconducting polymers that have lagged behind their p - type counterparts. 2 Organic n - type materials are essential for the fabrication of organic p-n junctions , OPVs , n-channel OFETs , OLEDs , and complementary logic circuits. 3 The n - type building blocks are the core components in n - type semiconducting polymers. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are one of the classical n - type building blocks and can exhibit relatively high electron affinities , high electron mobilities , and excellent chemical , thermal , and photochemical stabilities. 4 These materials are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated. The widely used rylene diimides include perylene diimides ( PDIs , 1 ) and naphthalene diimides ( NDIs , 2 ) ( Figure 1 ). Zhan and co-workers reported the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer. 5 Top-gate OFETs based on this PDI- dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility ( μ e ) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , current on / off ratio ( I on / I off ) of 10^4 , and a low threshold voltage ( V th ) of 7 V in air. 6 Moreover , all - polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 1.5% ( AM1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 ). 7-9 Facchetti et al. reported a conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene ; 10 OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate , bottom - contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μ e of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with I on / I off > 10^5 . 11 The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide ( 3 ) and thiophene imide ( 4 ) ( Figure 1 ). A few literatures reported phthalimide - containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s , 12 a polyaniline derivative , 13 and a polythiophene derivative.

Let's think step by step.

1. Significant progress in synthesis of conjugated polymers
2. Type of optoelectronic devices: organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), organic photovoltaic cells (OPVs), organic field-effect transistors (OFETs)
3. Advantages of optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers: low-cost, light-weight, flexibility
4. Conjugated polymers: hole (p-type) or electron (n-type) transporting materials
5. Essential organic n-type materials for fabrication of organic p-n junctions, OPVs, n-channel OFETs, OLEDs, and complementary logic circuits
6. N-type building blocks in n-type semiconducting polymers
7. Aromatic imides: rylene diimides, perylene diimides (PDIs), naphthalene diimides (NDIs)
8. Electron affinities, electron mobilities, and excellent chemical, thermal, and photochemical stabilities of aromatic imides
9. Saturation electron mobility (μe), current on/off ratio (I on/I off), and low threshold voltage (Vth) of top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer
10. Power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of all-polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors
11. Conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene, OFET devices based on this polymer, μe under ambient conditions, I on/I off ratio
12. Phthalimide and thiophene imide
13. Few reported phthalimide-containing conjugated polymers: poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s, a polyaniline derivative, a polythiophene derivative.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| Significant progress in synthesis of conjugated polymers |
| Type of optoelectronic devices: organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), organic photovoltaic cells (OPVs), organic field-effect transistors (OFETs) |
| Advantages of optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers: low-cost, light-weight, flexibility |
| Conjugated polymers: hole (p-type) or electron (n-type) transporting materials |
| Essential organic n-type materials for fabrication of organic p-n junctions, OPVs, n-channel OFETs, OLEDs, and complementary logic circuits |
| N-type building blocks in n-type semiconducting polymers |
| Electron affinities, electron mobilities, and excellent chemical, thermal, and photochemical stabilities of aromatic imides |
| Saturation electron mobility (μe), current on/off ratio (I on/I off), and low threshold voltage (Vth) of top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer |
| Power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of all-polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors |
| Conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene, OFET devices based on this polymer, μe under ambient conditions, I on/I off ratio |
| Phthalimide and thiophene imide |
| Few reported phthalimide-containing conjugated polymers: poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s, a polyaniline derivative, a polythiophene derivative. |

* Few reported phthalimide-containing conjugated polymers: poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s, a polyaniline derivative, a polythiophene derivative.

Paragraph: Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers and their applications for optoelectronic device such as organic light - emitting diodes ( OLEDs ) , organic photovoltaic cells ( OPVs ) , and organic field - effect transistors ( OFETs ) since Heeger , MacDiarmid , and Shirakawa discovered conducting polymers in 1976.^1 As a result of the low - cost , light - weight , and flexibility advantages , optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers are a promising cost - effective alternative to inorganic materials - based microelectronics. Conjugated polymers can be classified as hole ( p - type ) or electron ( n - type ) transporting materials according to the type of orderly transferring charge carriers. Most of conjugated polymers are p - type semiconductors that have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade while much less attention has been devoted to n - type semiconducting polymers that have lagged behind their p - type counterparts. 2 Organic n - type materials are essential for the fabrication of organic p-n junctions , OPVs , n-channel OFETs , OLEDs , and complementary logic circuits. 3 The n - type building blocks are the core components in n - type semiconducting polymers. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are one of the classical n - type building blocks and can exhibit relatively high electron affinities , high electron mobilities , and excellent chemical , thermal , and photochemical stabilities. 4 These materials are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated. The widely used rylene diimides include perylene diimides ( PDIs , 1 ) and naphthalene diimides ( NDIs , 2 ) ( Figure 1 ). Zhan and co-workers reported the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer. 5 Top-gate OFETs based on this PDI- dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility ( μ e ) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , current on / off ratio ( I on / I off ) of 10^4 , and a low threshold voltage ( V th ) of 7 V in air. 6 Moreover , all - polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 1.5% ( AM1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 ). 7-9 Facchetti et al. reported a conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene ; 10 OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate , bottom - contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μ e of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with I on / I off > 10^5 . 11 The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide ( 3 ) and thiophene imide ( 4 ) ( Figure 1 ). A few literatures reported phthalimide - containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s , 12 a polyaniline derivative , 13 and a polythiophene derivative.

Let's think step by step.

1. Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers since 1976. (No specific value provided)
2. Conjugated polymers are a promising cost-effective alternative to inorganic materials-based microelectronics. (No specific value provided)
3. Most of conjugated polymers are p-type semiconductors. (No specific value provided)
4. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides can exhibit relatively high electron affinities. (No specific value provided)
5. Top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility (μe) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1.
6. Top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a current on/off ratio (I on/I off) of 10^4.
7. Top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a low threshold voltage (Vth) of 7 V in air.
8. All-polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) as high as 1.5%.
9. OFET devices based on NDI-bithiophene copolymer exhibited μe of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 under ambient conditions.
10. OFET devices based on NDI-bithiophene copolymer exhibited I on/I off > 10^5.
11. The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide. (No specific value provided)
12. Poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s contain phthalimide. (No specific value provided)
13. A polyaniline derivative contains phthalimide. (No specific value provided)
14. A polythiophene derivative contains phthalimide. (No specific value provided)

| --- |
| Saturation electron mobility (μe) of PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer in OFETs: 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 |
| Current on/off ratio (I on/I off) of PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer in OFETs: 10^4 |
| Threshold voltage (Vth) of PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer in OFETs in air: 7 V |
| Power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of all-polymer solar cells: as high as 1.5% |
| μe of NDI-bithiophene copolymer in OFETs under ambient conditions: 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 |
| I on/I off of NDI-bithiophene copolymer in OFETs: > 10^5 |
